guides.title: α ε κ μ τ
guides.sourceContent:
Let’s start with the easy letters. They’re basically just English ones dressed up in a different skin (though, since the English—or Latin—alphabet comes from Greek, these are actually the originals).

## Words

With just those letters, you can already say a (slightly random) selection of Greek words:

Words

guides.title: Alphabet
guides.sourceContent:
If you’ve read the other guides so far, you might already have picked up some idea about which Greek letters are which.

There are only 24 letters in the Greek alphabet, so it’s even less to learn than English, and a bunch of them make the same sound as each other and their English counterparts.

Here’s the whole alphabet:

<el-alphabet class="section" />

Some are familiar: Α, Ε, Ζ, Ι, etc., but others totally not. What on earth is a Ξ, or a Ψ? We’ll plumb the murky alphabetical depths in small groups of letters to find out.
guides.renderedContent:

guides.title: είμαι/to be
guides.sourceContent:
This is a quick guide about the verb 'to be'.

In Greek, 'to be' is 'είμαι'. That doesn't look like any other verbs we've seen so far, right? Why does it end in 'μαι' instead of 'ω'?

Etc.
